newsitem.title: CANADA: BASEBALL-CLEMENS GOES TO 11-0 AS JAYS BEAT ATHLETICS.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-CLEMENS GOES TO 11-0 AS JAYS BEAT ATHLETICS.

text.p: Roger Clemens made Carlos Delgado's first-inning grand slam stand up as he pitched eight shutout innings Friday for his major league-leading 11th win in the Blue Jays' 4-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

With the win, Clemens (11-0) matched Dennis Lamp's 1985 team record for the longest winning streak to start a season and continued to justify Toronto's faith in signing him to a huge free-agent contract in the off-season.
"It's great when it comes in this fashion," said Clemens. "We got runs early and I was able to keep them at bay."
The big right-hander, who checked the Athletics on five hits and struck out eight, exceeded his win total for all of 1996, when he went 10-13 with the Boston Red Sox.

The victory snapped Toronto's four-game losing streak and marked the second time in less than a week Clemens has beaten Oakland to snap a four-game skid by the Jays. In their last 11 games, Toronto is 3-8 with Clemens picking up all three wins.
Delgado's grand slam off Mike Oquist (1-2) was his 11th home run of the year and third in three games.

Mark McGwire scored Oakland's only run of the game with a homer off reliever Mike Timlin. It was McGwire's 23rd homer of the season and the 352nd of his career, moving him into 46th place on the all-time list, breaking a tie with Dick Allen.
At Minnesota, Paul Molitor slugged a three-run homer in the eighth inning - his fourth hit of the game - to snap a 6-6 tie and lift the Twins to a 9-7 win over the Anaheim Angels.
Molitor's game-winning blast came off reliever Pep Harris.
"I have seen this guy pitch, but I hadn't faced him," said Molitor. He kept pounding that sinker down and in. It was nice to see it go out."
Said Harris: "That pitch was basically on the ground."
Minnesota manager Tom Kelly enjoyed himself.
"Very entertaining ballgame," Minnesota manager Tom Kelly said. "We got behind, came back, took the lead, got behind, came back, tied it up, and then Paulie certainly got a big hit for us."

In Detroit, promising Jose Cruz Jr. belted a pair of two-run homers and fellow rookie Derek Lowe went 5 1/3 innings for his first big-league victory as the Mariners posted their fifth straight win, 6-3 over the Detroit Tigers.

Cruz, playing just his sixth major-league game, hit his first homer of the game and second of the season off starter Omar Olivares (4-4) in the second inning to stake Seattle to a 2-0 lead. He connected off Olivares again in the sixth to extend the Mariners' edge to 6-3.
Lowe (1-1), from nearby Dearborn, Michigan, allowed three runs and five hits. Bobby Ayala notched the save.
In Boston, Sandy Alomar stroked four consecutive doubles and Orel Hershiser allowed just one run over seven innings as the Cleveland Indians cruised to a 7-3 win over the Red Sox.
Alomar doubled in the second, fourth, fifth and eighth innings to become the 16th player in major-league history to hit four doubles in a row.
The last Indians player to hit four straight doubles was Vic Wertz in 1956. The last major-leaguer to perform the feat was Oakland's Dave Duncan in 1975.
Hershiser (6-2) took the win, and Tom Gordon (3-6) the loss.

In Chicago, Lyle Mouton highlighted a five-run fifth inning with a two-run double and Albert Belle went 4-for-4 as the Chicago White Sox ended Baltimore's seven-game winning streak with a 7-3 victory over the Orioles.
Chicago broke open a 2-2 tie with five runs in the fifth against starter Scott Erickson (8-2).
Doug Drabek (5-4) won for the fourth time in five decisions, allowing two runs and eight hits in 5 1/3 innings.
In New York, Kenny Rogers allowed three runs over 5 1/3 innings and four relievers combined to hold the Brewers hitless the rest of the way as the New York Yankees defeated the Brewers 6-3.
Rogers (4-3) survived six hits and four walks to post his first win since May 15.
Every Yankee batter had a hit and all but one drew a walk as New York overcame an early 2-0 deficit to make a loser out of Brewers starter Jose Mercedes (2-2).
Todd Dunn hit his first major-league homer for Milwaukee.
In Kansas City, Jose Rosado pitched a complete-game five-hitter as the Royals edged the Texas Rangers 2-1.

Catcher Sal Fasano scored the winning run on Jay Bell's infield single in the fifth inning off Texas starter John Burkett (4-5), who also went the distance, yielding just one earned one on seven hits.
Rosado improved to 5-3.
